instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
Customer said laptop was in cupboard for a few months. Laptop is suspiciously clean...
MagSafe gets Green & Orange light.

Fan doesn't do the start-stop-start-stop thing; it just turns on then slowly spins faster and faster till it reaches warp-speed.

No backlight or any other signs of life.

I don't even know where to start looking; 99% of my repairs are dead or liquid damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: check power rails, find whats missing, you can skip s5 s4 and s3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: measure cpu vcore, check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> if no vcore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 17033"]measure cpu vcore, check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> if no vcore. [/QUOTE]

do you sleep?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="peterfixit, post: 17036"]

do you sleep?[/QUOTE]

Not at the moment, no. haha.

Anyway, back to the point;

<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> == 91k. So it's within spec.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: i ment louis, its 2am there,, if it was me id change <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> or check voltage on working board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="peterfixit, post: 17043"]i ment louis, its 2am there,, if it was me id change <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> or check voltage on working board[/QUOTE]

I thought it was an odd question. lol

I don't have a board to test with. It measures right, I think <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> might be pulling it low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: its unusual for a resistor to pull down the voltage that much, does it visually look fucked up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
It wouldn't be the resistor pulling it down, wouldn't <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> be pulling it down?

Just to check my thought process;
That's why <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>::2 is higher than <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>::1. The resister is restricting the flow, allowing the difference.
If <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> had 0 resistance (just for example), then voltage would be the same both sides and some component further up the ::2 side of the line would be getting hot.

Board looks spotless.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: resistors usually fail by increasing resistance, caps turn into a wire. so, resistance to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: Fan ramping up is just that the CPU is not running. This one is going to suck probably. I would first try a known good BIOS chip, besides that there is not much you can do if it is not a liquid damage. Save the original BIOS file!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
Is it possible to buy the header clip for the diagnostic port?

Would make flashing the bios a lot quicker if I could build a little adapter for it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: Pretty sure you can find it, but it would require research. I have no time to mess with that. I doubt it will be the BIOS though, just a last ditch effort.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
I managed to find the connector. I flash these things just often enough that it's probably worth having a jig.

I have two boards now that are doing the same thing.
Should I throw then in the bin, or keep trying?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: FYI, those connectors are garbage. You'll go crazy getting corrupted/partial dumps, read/write errors, "no chip found", etc. Really aggravating. Better to just take 3 minutes to solder wires or pull the chip. Just a suggestion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message:
Thanks for the heads up.
I did experience something similar with a clothes-peg-adapter I built a few years back now. Maybe pulling them off is a cleaner solution.
Once an EFI chip (13"Retina board) cracked in half when it came off and it turned into a nightmare. So I've been reluctant to pull them off unless I have to ever since. Of course you could say it was already compromised which is what lead me to remove and flash it in the first place.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Fan spins high.
threads.message: You have 2 boards that have the same? The most common case is liquid or someone stabbed a component off. BIOS is last ditch.....
